question: What are some losses that Churchill car insurance does not cover?
reference_answer: Churchill car insurance does not cover loss, damage, liability or injury caused by identifiable pollution or contamination, unless it’s come from a sudden and unexpected accident. It also does not cover any injury, loss, damage or liability caused by war, invasion, revolution, military or usurped power or arising from Government Action or a similar event except as is strictly required under the Road Traffic Act. It won't cover any loss or damage to your car or property caused by riot or civil commotion outside Great Britain, the Isle of Man or the Channel Islands. Additionally, it does not cover any loss or damage caused by a government agency or other authority that legally takes, keeps or destroys your car. It also does not cover any liability under any separate agreement or contract you’ve made, unless you’d have been responsible even if that agreement or contract didn’t exist, and any loss or damage to property, any direct or indirect loss, or any expense, or any liability caused, or contributed to, by ionising radiation or radioactive contamination from nuclear fuel or waste.

question: What is the policy for lost or stolen car keys while driving abroad?
reference_answer: While driving your car abroad, the car keys are covered if they are stolen or lost under two conditions: if you have Comprehensive cover and you've added Foreign Use Extension to your cover before you travel, or if you have Comprehensive Plus cover, where 90 days of Foreign Use Extension is included for each insured period. If your keys are lost or stolen, you'll need to replace them and send the receipts to the insurance company for reimbursement. However, the insurance doesn't cover any reduction in your car's market value because of stolen keys or losses that aren't directly due to your keys being stolen.

question: What does 'Written off' mean in the context of car insurance?
reference_answer: 'Written off' refers to when your car is so badly damaged that it’s no longer roadworthy, or the cost to fix it would be uneconomical, based on its market value.

question: If I am residing in either Jersey, Guernsey, Alderney or the Isle of Man, could you specify which jurisdiction's law will be applied to my policy?
reference_answer: If you are resident in Jersey, Guernsey, Alderney or the Isle of Man, the law of the island where you are resident will always apply to your policy and any dispute in relation to it will be within the jurisdiction of that island’s relevant court.
reference_context:

We’ve supplied this policy and other information to you in English and we’ll continue to communicate with you in English.

question: Could you explain the process Churchill car insurance follows if a scheduled installment payment for the policy isn't able to be collected, including any notifications or actions taken?
reference_answer: If the installment payment(s) due under your credit agreement cannot be collected on the due date(s), Churchill will write to you to give you the opportunity to make the payment(s). If any installment amount remains unpaid by the date set out in their letter, they will give you 7 days’ notice that they will cancel your policy, and inform you in writing when this cancellation has taken place.

Paying your premium

If you change your car insurance and there’s an extra premium to pay, you can pay this at the time of the change, or add it to your monthly payments.

What happens if we can’t collect your payment

If we have been unable to collect the instalment payment(s) due under your credit agreement on the date(s) due, we will write to you in order to give you the opportunity to make the payment(s).

question: In the event of dissatisfaction with the coverage for liability and fire and theft under the Comprehensive Plus plan, how can I escalate my complaint to the Financial Ombudsman Service?
reference_answer: The Comprehensive Plus cover includes unlimited coverage for injuries to other people under the liability section. It also provides coverage for property damage up to £20,000,000 per accident. In terms of fire and theft, it covers the market value for fire damage to your car and theft or attempted theft of your car. It also includes unlimited coverage for child car seat replacement and in-car entertainment fitted in your car when it was made. For in-car entertainment fitted in your car after it was made, it provides £2,000 coverage. For removable electronic equipment, it provides £2,000 coverage.

question: Given the scenario where I fail to provide acceptable proof of NCD and my policy cost increases, how would the cost and benefits of 'Guaranteed Hire Car Plus' and 'Courtesy car' cover in Churchill car insurance be affected?
reference_answer: The Guaranteed Hire Car Plus aims to provide a hire car of a similar size to your car if it is damaged, written off or stolen. This cover is included in the Comprehensive Plus package and is an optional extra for Essentials and Comprehensive packages. However, it is not included with Third Party, Fire and Theft. On the other hand, the Courtesy Car cover provides a small hatchback car, regardless of the size or style of your own car. This cover is included with Third Party, Fire and Theft, Essentials, and Comprehensive packages if you haven’t picked Guaranteed Hire Car Plus. It is not included with Comprehensive Plus because it’s replaced by Guaranteed Hire Car Plus.

question: How does the concept of 'Modifications' apply to my car insurance policy when it comes to repairs and replacements carried out by your approved repairer?
reference_answer: Modifications refer to any changes to your car’s standard specification, including optional extras. These include changes to the appearance or the performance of your car, including wheels, suspension, bodywork and engine. Modifications also include changes made to your car by a previous owner.

Modifications Any changes to your car’s standard specification, including optional extras.

Modifications include changes to the appearance or the performance of your car, including wheels, suspension, bodywork and engine. Please note this is not a complete list. Modifications include changes made to your car by a previous owner.

NCD owner The person who has earned the No Claim Discount (NCD) that is in use on this policy.

Partner Your husband, wife, or civil partner, or someone you’re living with as if you’re married to them.

question: As I'm researching about my new car insurance policy with Churchill and trying to understand claims, benefits, and accidental damage, could you tell me who regulates U K Insurance Limited?
reference_answer: U K Insurance Limited is authorised by the Prudential Regulation Authority and regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority and the Prudential Regulation Authority.
reference_context:
Document 113: Our regulator

U K Insurance Limited is authorised by the Prudential Regulation Authority and regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority and the Prudential Regulation Authority under registration number 202810. The Financial Conduct Authority website, which includes a register of all regulated firms, can be visited at www.fca.org.uk, or the Financial Conduct Authority can be contacted on 0800 111 6768.

Financial Services Compensation Scheme

General insurance claims are covered by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme. Full details of the cover available can be found at www.fscs.org.uk. U K Insurance Limited is a member of this scheme.

Everything else

The Motor Insurance Database

question: As a frustrated customer, I had an issue that wasn't resolved in my favor. What is the procedure I should follow to lodge a complaint about my Green Flag breakdown cover with Churchill car insurance company?
reference_answer: If you have a complaint about your Green Flag breakdown cover, you should let the company know when you get in touch. The staff will do everything they can to support you and aim to resolve most issues within three working days of receiving your complaint. If your complaint can’t be resolved within three working days, they will contact you to let you know who’ll be dealing with it, and what the next steps are.
reference_context:

If you have a complaint

How we can help

If something’s not right, please call us on: > 0800 051 0198 if you’re in the UK. > +44 (0) 141 349 0193 if you’re outside the UK.

How to make a complaint

If you have Green Flag breakdown cover and your complaint is about your breakdown cover, please let us know when you get in touch.

Our staff will do everything they can to support you. We’ll aim to resolve most issues within three working days of receiving your complaint.

We understand that things don’t always go to plan and there may be times when you feel we’ve let you down. If this happens, we want you to tell us. We’ll do our best to put things right as soon as possible, or explain something we could have made clearer.

Please call us on 0800 051 0198 to speak to us about your problem.

If your complaint can’t be resolved within three working days, we’ll contact you to let you know who’ll be dealing with it, and what the next steps are.

question: As a car owner who just recently got into an accident, could you explain the conditions under which the insurance company will compensate for my accidental injury? I'm trying to understand the extent of my personal injury coverage.
reference_answer: The insurance company will pay if you or your partner are accidentally injured while travelling in or getting in or out of your car. The injury should cause death, total irrecoverable loss of sight in one or both eyes, or loss of any limb within three calendar months. The company will only pay out once in any period of insurance and won't cover any injury or death caused by suicide or attempted suicide.

question: What are the steps to follow and what information will I need to provide if I need to make a claim?
reference_answer: First, take photos of the accident if it’s safe to do so, including any vehicles involved. Then, ask the other party for their contact details. If any passers-by have stopped, you can ask for their contact details. Then, call Churchill as soon as possible. To get the ball rolling, Churchill will need to know things like: Your personal details, Your policy number, Your car registration number, A description of the loss or damage, and if you’ve been in an accident, the other driver’s details.

question: What happens if I have made a claim and I owe money to the insurance company, or if I owe an additional premium at the time of a claim?
reference_answer: If you have made a claim, or one has been made against you before the date that the insurance policy is cancelled, you must pay all instalment payments that have already fallen due and remain unpaid, as well as the total remaining balance. The insurance company may reduce the amount they pay in settlement of your claim by the amount that you owe them. Alternatively, if you are in arrears at the time of the claim, they may refuse your claim. Similarly, if you owe an additional premium at the time of a claim, the insurance company may refuse your claim or deduct the additional premium from any claim payment they make to you, or they may proportionately reduce any claim payment.
reference_context:
Document 102: If your credit agreement is cancelled, the cancellation date may be different to the cancellation date of the insurance policy.

Page 38

If there’s a claim while you owe us money

If you have made a claim, or one has been made against you before the date that we cancel the policy you must pay to us (1) all instalment payments that have already fallen due under the credit agreement and remain unpaid, and (2) the total remaining balance under the credit agreement. If we agree to pay your claim and you have not paid the amounts due to us under (1) and (2) above, we may reduce the amount that we pay in settlement of your claim by the amount that you owe us. Alternatively, if you are in arrears at the time of the claim, we may refuse your claim.

If you owe us an additional premium

We may refuse your claim. If we agree to allow your claim, we may deduct any additional premium from any claim payment we make to you, or we may proportionately reduce any claim payment.

question: Which countries does the minimum car insurance cover and what are its limitations in the rest of Europe?
reference_answer: The minimum car insurance covers any country which is a member of the European Union and countries such as Andorra, Austria, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Gibraltar, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Montenegro, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, and Switzerland. However, in the rest of Europe, the cover does not apply if anyone is driving a car other than your car, if you have a courtesy car, it cannot be used outside the territorial limits, and if you have Guaranteed Hire Car Plus, and you have been provided with a hire car, this policy doesn’t give you cover to drive outside the territorial limits.

original_questions.question: Which countries does the minimum car insurance cover?
original_questions.answer: The minimum car insurance covers any country which is a member of the European Union and countries such as Andorra, Austria, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Gibraltar, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Montenegro, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, and Switzerland.

original_questions.question: What are the limitations of the car insurance cover in the rest of Europe?
original_questions.answer: In the rest of Europe, the cover does not apply if anyone is driving a car other than your car, if you have a courtesy car, it cannot be used outside the territorial limits, and if you have Guaranteed Hire Car Plus, and you have been provided with a hire car, this policy doesn’t give you cover to drive outside the territorial limits.

question: What is the policy regarding repairs at a repairer of my choice, and what is the policy for windscreen repairs and replacements?
reference_answer: Reasonable and necessary repairs can be carried out at a repairer of your choice if agreed upon, with the repairer’s detailed assessment of the repairs approved before the work begins, but these repairs will not be guaranteed by the insurance company. For windscreen repairs or replacements, if you arrange them with someone who isn’t an approved windscreen supplier, you don’t need to get the insurance company's approval beforehand, but they will only cover a limited amount, with the excess amounts shown on your car insurance details.
reference_context:
Document 17: Where we have agreed this with you, reasonable and necessary repairs can be carried out at a repairer of your choice. However, you must give us full details of the incident and we must approve the repairer’s detailed assessment of the repairs before the work begins. We may then make the arrangements for the repairs ourselves.

Where the repairs are carried out at a repairer of your choice, those repairs will NOT be guaranteed by us even though we may pay for them directly. For the purposes of this policy, those repairs will not be treated as being carried out by our approved repairer.

If there is a problem with any aspect of the repair, your first port of call is the repairer who did the original work. If you’re still unhappy with any aspect of the repairs, please let us know.

Windscreen repairs

We may decide to replace your car’s glass with glass that hasn’t been made by your car’s manufacturer but is of a similar standard.

Document 18: If you arrange windscreen repairs or replacement with someone who isn’t an approved windscreen supplier, you don’t need to get our approval beforehand. However, we’ll only cover a limited amount – see ‘Section 5: Windscreen damage’ on page 20.

Making a claim

The excess amounts for windscreen repairs and replacement are shown on your car insurance details.

Replacing parts in your car

We may decide to repair your car with parts that haven’t been made by your car’s manufacturer, but that are of a similar standard. This can include recycled parts. If any part or accessory is not available, the most we’ll pay for that part will be the cost shown in the manufacturer’s last UK price list (plus reasonable fitting costs).

Removing, delivering and storing your car

If we’re dealing with your claim under sections 2 or 4 of your policy and your car can’t be driven, we’ll cover reasonable costs to take it to the nearest suitable repairer.

question: What steps should be followed in this situation?
reference_answer: 1. Safety comes first. Stop at the scene of the accident and if there are any injuries or if any driver involved hasn’t stopped, call the police and emergency services. 2. Take photos of the accident if it’s safe to do so, including any vehicles involved.
reference_context:
Document 121: If your complaint is to do with your Motor Legal Cover

If your complaint relates to Section 7: Motor Legal Cover, you can refer your complaint to arbitration instead (where an independent person, known as an arbitrator, makes a decision to settle the dispute). The arbitrator will be a solicitor or barrister or other suitably qualified person that you and we agree on. If you and we cannot agree, then we’ll ask the Chartered Institute of Arbitrators to decide. The arbitrator’s decision will be final, and whoever doesn’t win will have to pay all costs and expenses.

If you’re in an accident

We’re here to support you when accidents happen, so we’ve put together some useful steps for you to follow to help make the process smoother.

1

Safety comes first

Stop at the scene of the accident and if there are any injuries or if any driver involved hasn’t stopped, call the police and emergency services.

2

Take photos of the accident if it’s safe to do so, including any vehicles involved
